Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Computational Multibody Dynamics: Addressing Modeling and Simulation Limitations in Problems with Friction and Contact

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Program project brings together a research group from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and a team of engineers from Caterpillar in a joint effort that aims at investigating and experimentally validating modeling and numerical solution methods capable of predicting through computer simulation the time evolution of large dynamic systems. The proposed research, development, and validation effort will increase the role that computer simulation plays in investigating processes such as transporting, mixing, and compacting discrete material (powders, grains, gravel, rocks). Although these processes are relevant in a broad spectrum of industries: e.g., manufacturing, construction, farming, food and drug, their investigation through computer modeling and simulation provides limited benefit today unless the problem size and/or duration of the analysis are drastically curtailed, often below practically useful limits. Better understanding the dynamics of large multibody systems is important since after water, discrete media are manipulated in industry the most. Moreover, about 50% of all traded products worldwide are in granular form and their manufacturing, transport, processing, packing and mixing pose challenging problems in which the outcomes of this research is anticipated to provide valuable insights.

The granular systems to be investigated have millions to billions of components whose collective behavior is dominated by frictional contact interactions between individual elements. The research effort will concentrate on (1) investigating two classes of solutions methods; i.e., Krylov-subspace and Primal-Dual Interior Point methods, to address current numerical solution limitations that stem from the multiscale aspect of practical applications; (2) investigate augmented Lagrangian formulations to understand whether they can enhance the modeling role that complementarity approaches play in multibody dynamics; and (3) compare two classes of solution methods; i.e., penalty-based and complementarity-based, in terms of accuracy, robustness and scalability in order to compile a factual body of evidence that summarizes the advantages and disadvantages of each approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this project, the PI and a group of graduate and undergraduate students have investigated, implemented and demonstrated two efficient and accurate numerical methods for solving frictional contact problems encountered in large-scale computational multi-body dynamics (CMBD). One prime example of such problem is the dynamics analysis of granular materials. The modeling and numerical solution methods established achieve fast convergence rate and high accuracy when compared with the state of the art. We implemented a first order method that is matrix-free and as such is suitable for solving large CMBD problems containing of the order of 10 to 50 million degrees of freedom. This is the type of problem that turns out to be of interest to our Caterpillar collaborators, who, on a daily basis handle terramechanics problems. Moreover, we established a more accurate and faster method that works for smaller size problems usually encountered in classical multibody dynamics applications such as robotics. Therein, the assumption is that the number of degrees of freedom is in the hundreds and up to thousands. For these problems, the solution established falls back on a matrix-method (primal-dual interior point algorithm) associated with the minimization of a cost function subject to conic constraints. The research outcomes of this project have been reported in nine journal papers, three book chapters and eight technical reports (available online). Of the journal papers, an ACM manuscript describes the matrix-free method, a CMAME manuscript describes the primal-dual interior point algorithm, and a PhysRev.E paper investigates the predictive attribute of the methods developed in this project. For this task, we carried out a validation process that points out some strengths and limitations of the methods developed.

 

 

In terms of broader impact, in each year of this project we organized the “Promoting the Computational Science Initiative'' (ProCSI) program. Through this residential camp, high school students from underrepresented socioeconomic groups, who most often come from low-income families, spent an inspiring week on campus at UW-Madison having room and board covered. The high school students participate in Computational Science related activities, including: introduction to computational dynamics through development of a basic video game, aspects of Computer Aided Design and concepts of Computer Graphics. A thorough description of ProCSI's statement of purpose, activities, schedule, and more than 500 pictures are available online. To date, approximately 150 underrepresented high-school students from Wisconsin, Illinois, Tennessee, California, Missouri, Oklahoma, Iowa, Minnesota, Arkansas and Guam have gone through our residential program. As proved by the exit interviews available online, the high school students leave the program extremely motivated by the on campus experience. They interact with UW-Madison students, they understand that they belong, and are inspired to envision their own trajectory in higher education. Run on a volunteer basis, ProCSI has been streamlined in many respects: from the online application process, to handling of the students' health insurance, to round table discussion with minority engineering undergraduate students, to visits to campus landmarks and on to recreational activities. In terms of impact assessment, the web-based Student Assessment of Learning Gains Instrument (SALGI), developed by the National Institute for Science Education (NISE) College Level One Team under NSF support at the University of Wisconsin, is used for outcome control and implementation of a continuous improvement process.

 

 

One of the priorities in this GOALI project was to emphasize the task of transfer of technology. Each year, the PI and several of his students visited the Caterpillar Technical Center in Peoria Illinois (last time on August 10, 2018). The Caterpillar collaborator and several of his colleagues visited the university at least once every year. The outcome of this interaction was a two-way transfer of information that benefitted both ends. Caterpillar re-wrote their granular dynamics code, which now runs between 100 and 1000 times faster than before. Negrut received research feedback and validation guidance for the basic modeling and algorithmic work done at the university. Almost all the algorithms and methods investigated under this project found their way in an open source simulation environment called Chrono. This software infrastructure is available online (GitHub) and can be freely used by any individual interested in large-scale, multi-physics applications. The Chrono user forum (hosted though Google Forum), currently has more than 200 worldwide registered users. Several simulation snapshots have been included. There are more than 150 simulation movies obtained with Chrono available online.

 

Further details pertaining the outcomes of this project are provided in several annual reports and one final project report.
